identificationModule.briefTitle: Inspiring Seniors Toward Exercise Promotion to Prevent Alzheimer's Disease
identificationModule.officialTitle: Music Stimulation for Physical Activity of Older Adults at Risk of Dementia

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The goal of this clinical trial is to test the benefits of beat-accented music stimulation (BMS) for behavioral changes of physical activity (PA) in older adults with subjective memory complaints. Specific Aims are to determine (1) whether BMS beneficially influences PA behaviors and psychological responses to PA in older adults for 6 months, and (2) whether exercising with BMS differently influences physical and cognitive functioning as well as quality of life in older adults.To test the effects of BMS on PA, participants will be randomly assigned to an exercise intervention that either includes BMS or does not include BMS. Participants will attend a supervised group strength training (ST) (30 min/day) and and aerobic exercise (AE) (30-50 min/day) session for 3 days/week for the first 2 months, 1 day/week for the next 2 months (while encouraging participants to independently perform both AE and ST on other days), and independently for the final 2 months (always with a goal of performing \>150min/week AE and 3 days/week of ST for 30 min/day).

armGroups.label: Exercise and music
armGroups.description: The strength training (ST) program incorporates single-leg exercises for balance training and training with resistance bands and body weight. During the ST, participants will be asked to synchronize their concentric and eccentric muscle contractions in time with the tempo of BMS playlists at a specific music tempo. For aerobic exercise (AE), participants will be instructed to walk at moderate intensity with duration increasing up to an ultimate goal of 150 min/week. Participants will be trained to walk in synchrony with the beats. Participants will receive individualized music playlists to match individual walking cadence and music preference.

armGroups.label: Exercise
armGroups.description: The ST program incorporates single-leg exercises for balance training and training with resistance bands and body weight. For AE, participants will be instructed to walk at moderate intensity with duration increasing up to an ultimate goal of 150 min/week.

interventions.name: Music
interventions.description: Those randomized to the exercise and music group will receive pre-recorded music playlists along with the exercise. During the strength training (ST), participants will be asked to sync their concentric and eccentric muscle contractions in time with the tempo of playlists. For aerobic exercise (AE), we will adjust the tempo of playlists to match individual walking cadence for participants to be trained to walk in sync with the beats of the playlists.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Changes of physical activity behaviors as assessed by ActiGraph wGT3X-BT
primaryOutcomes.description: Duration, intensity, and frequency of physical activity assessed using an waist-worn accelerometer
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: 7 consecutive days at Baseline (before the intervention) and during month 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6

primaryOutcomes.measure: Affective responses to physical activity as assessed by Physical Activity Enjoyment Scale
primaryOutcomes.description: Self-reported affective states relative to physical activity. Physical Activity Enjoyment Scale has 18 items based on a 7-point Likert scale and the total score is ranged from 18 to 126.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: At baseline (before the intervention), month 3 and month 5 during the intervention, and post-test (within 4 weeks after the intervention)

primaryOutcomes.measure: Adherence to the physical activity program
primaryOutcomes.description: Daily duration of aerobic exercise and strength training is self-reported on an exercise log.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: A daily exercise log for the entire 6-month period

secondaryOutcomes.measure: General cognition as assessed using the Montreal Cognitive Assessment
secondaryOutcomes.description: Montreal Cognitive Assessment takes approximately 10 minutes for completion and the total score is ranged from 0 to 30.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: At pre-test (before the intervention) and post-test (within 4 weeks after the intervention).

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Executive function as assessed using the Tower of London - Freiburg version
secondaryOutcomes.description: Tower of London - Freiburg version takes approximately 14 minutes to complete and measures the total number of items solved in minimum number of moves in the range from 0 to 12.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: At pre-test (before the intervention) and post-test (within 4 weeks after the intervention).

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Executive function as assessed using the NIH Toolbox Flanker Inhibitory Control and Attention test
secondaryOutcomes.description: The Flanker Inhibitory Control and Attention test takes approximately 5 minutes to complete and measures the accuracy and reaction time to create a composite score, ranging from 0 to 10.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: At pre-test (before the intervention) and post-test (within 4 weeks after the intervention).

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Executive function as assessed using the NIH Toolbox Dimensional Change Card Sort test
secondaryOutcomes.description: The Dimensional Change Card Sort test takes approximately 5 minutes to complete and measures the accuracy and reaction time to create a composite score, ranging from 0 to 10.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: At pre-test (before the intervention) and post-test (within 4 weeks after the intervention).

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Executive function as assessed using the NIH Toolbox List Sorting Working Memory test
secondaryOutcomes.description: The List Sorting Working Memory test takes approximately 10 minutes to complete and measures the total number of items correctly recalled and sequenced, ranging from 0 to 26.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: At pre-test (before the intervention) and post-test (within 4 weeks after the intervention).

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Episodic memory as assessed using the NIH Toolbox Picture Sequence Memory test
secondaryOutcomes.description: The Picture Sequence Memory test takes approximately 7 minutes to complete and measures the total number of items correctly placed, ranging from 0 to 31, and the IRT-based theta score, ranging from 200 to 700.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: At pre-test (before the intervention) and post-test (within 4 weeks after the intervention).

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Episodic memory as assessed using the Mnemonic Similarity Task
secondaryOutcomes.description: This custom-developed test takes approximately 15 minutes to complete and measures mnemonic discrimination (a score ranging from 0-1) and visual recognition (a score ranging from 0-1).
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: At pre-test (before the intervention) and post-test (within 4 weeks after the intervention).

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Health-related quality of life as assessed using the RAND 36-Item Short-Form Health Survey
secondaryOutcomes.description: The RAND 36-Item Short-Form Health Survey Scale has 36 items for self-report, takes 10-15 minutes to complete, and measures health-related quality of life with a score ranging from 0 - 100.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: At pre-test (before the intervention) and post-test (within 4 weeks after the intervention).

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Physical activity behaviors as assessed by physical activity and sedentary behaviour questionnaire.
secondaryOutcomes.description: The physical activity and sedentary behaviour questionnaire has 7 items and takes approximately 5 minutes for completion
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: At pre-test (before the intervention) and post-test (within 4 weeks after the intervention).

secondaryOutcomes.measure: The progress of aerobic capacity and endurance as assessed by 6-minute walk test
secondaryOutcomes.description: The distance covered over a time of 6 minutes is used as the outcome by which to compare changes in performance capacity.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: At pre-test (before the intervention) and post-test (within 4 weeks after the intervention).

secondaryOutcomes.measure: The progress of balance, sit-to-stand, and walking as assessed by Timed Up and Go test
secondaryOutcomes.description: The time taken to complete a Timed Up and Go test is an indicator of fall risks.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: At pre-test (before the intervention) and post-test (within 4 weeks after the intervention).

secondaryOutcomes.measure: The progress of lower-body strength as assessed by 30-Second Sit-to-Stand test
secondaryOutcomes.description: The number of sit-to-stand maneuvers completed in 30 seconds.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: At pre-test (before the intervention) and post-test (within 4 weeks after the intervention).

secondaryOutcomes.measure: The progress of upper-body strength as assessed by Grip Strength test
secondaryOutcomes.description: The squeeze power in pounds measured by by a handheld dynamometer
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: At pre-test (before the intervention) and post-test (within 4 weeks after the intervention).

secondaryOutcomes.measure: The progress of balance as assessed by 4-Stage Balance Test
secondaryOutcomes.description: The duration of maintaining 4 difference postures
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: At pre-test (before the intervention) and post-test (within 4 weeks after the intervention).

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Individual differences in music-related reward experiences as assessed by the Barcelona Music Reward Questionnaire (BMRQ)
secondaryOutcomes.description: BMRQ has 24 items and takes 5-10 minutes to complete and measures music-related reward experiences with a score ranging from 0 to 100.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: At pre-test (before the intervention) and post-test (within 4 weeks after the intervention).

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Treatment satisfaction as assessed by the Client Satisfaction Questionnaire (CSQ-8)
secondaryOutcomes.description: CSQ has 8 items and takes approximately 3 minutes to complete and measures self-reported satisfaction with the program with a score ranging from 0 to 32.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: At post-test (within 4 weeks after the intervention).

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Adults at least 65 years old.
* Ambulatory/capable of walking for 6 minutes without pain or aid such as a walker/cane.
* Able to speak and read English.
* Healthy enough to exercise at moderate intensity with or without medical clearance by a primary care physician.
* Living in the community for the duration of the study (6 months).
* Having a reliable means of transportation.
* Having a safe place (at least 6 feet by 6 feet of open space) at home for unsupervised exercise training.
* Having self-perceived memory complaints.
* Having no symptoms of suicidal ideation and not meeting criteria for depressive disorder.
* Physically low-active by doing \< 60 min/week of moderate-intensity aerobic exercise and no strength training for the last 3 months.

Exclusion Criteria:

* Diagnosis of neurological disorder or spinal cord disorder.
* Known exercise contraindications.
* Current cancer treatment.
* Stroke or neural impairment in the past 6 months.
* Hip/knee/spinal fracture or surgery in the past 6 month.
* Unable or unwilling to attend intervention classes 3x/week in Months 1-2 and 1x/week in Months 3-4.
* Currently participating in any other physical activity or fitness-related research study.
* Use of medication for Alzheimer's disease. Change in dosage of medications prescribed for anxiety or depression within the previous 6 months.
* Regularly drink \> 14 alcoholic beverages a week or current illicit drug use.
* Meet the threshold for cognitive impairment.
* Meet the threshold for clinical depression.
* Uncorrected hearing or visual impairments.
* Unable to understand the study procedures.
* One of the household members is participating in this study.

references.citation: Park KS, Williams DM, Etnier JL. Exploring the use of music to promote physical activity: From the viewpoint of psychological hedonism. Front Psychol. 2023 Jan 25;14:1021825. doi: 10.3389/fpsyg.2023.1021825. eCollection 2023.

browseLeaves.name: Aluminum hydroxide, magnesium hydroxide, simethicone drug combination
